newsitem.title: BRAZIL: Brazil puts 288.5 pct tariff on Chinese pencils.
newsitem.headline: Brazil puts 288.5 pct tariff on Chinese pencils.

text.p: The Brazilian government Monday imposed a 288.5 percent tariff on imports of pencils from China, citing the need for "anti-dumping" measures after serious damage to the domestic industry.
In a long-awaited decree published in the Official Journal, Brazil said the punitive tariffs would apply for six months.
The decree said pencil imports had soared from $334 million in 1991 to $956.7 million in 1992 and had continued to rise since then.
China accounted for 74.7 percent of imports in 1995, increasing its sales by 230 percent between 1993 and 1994 and 144.3 percent between 1994 and 1995.
The decree said local employment in the pencil industry had slumped 22.3 percent between 1991 and 1995.
Industry and Commerce Minister Francisco Dornelles approved the tariff increase from 18 percent more than a month ago.
But the anti-dumping measure had been awaiting the approval of Finance Minister Pedro Malan, said to be concerned by recent moves interpreted as "protectionist".
Since Dornelles assumed office in May, Brazil has set quotas on textile imports and raised tariffs on toy imports to 70 percent from 20 percent.

It is also embroiled in a World Trade Organization dispute with the United States, Japan, South Korea and the European Union over car rules that allow manufacturers with Brazilian factories to import at preferential tariffs.
